column1: This course combines historical and theoretical perspectives on the place of the body in culture, from early modernity through to modernist conceptions of embodiment. The classes will examine specific literary texts, including Montaigne, Shakespeare, Mary Shelley, and Joyce, alongside theorists of the body, including Bakhtin, Nietzsche, Freud and Lacan. Some questions we will explore include: What part does the body play in the construction of self and other? What makes bodies such compelling objects of desire or repulsion? How is the immediate materiality of the body represented in literary texts? How, conversely, can the body itself be 'written' - marked and changed by ideological and historical forces? What, ultimately, can we say about the enigmatic relation between the body and language?
Friday Oct. 6th: Preliminary meeting (approx. half an hour)
Topics to include: subjectivity, objectivity and the body
